user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_mark_closed_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_mark_closed_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TURBO))
  {
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
    /* For TLS connection use shutdown of TLS layer
     * and do not shutdown TCP socket. This give more
     * chances to send TLS closure data to remote side.
     * Closure of TLS layer will be interpreted by
     * remote side as end of transmission. */
    if (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS))
    {
      if (! MHD_tls_connection_shutdown (connection))
        shutdown (connection->socket_fd,
                  SHUT_WR);
    }
    else   /* Combined with next 'shutdown()'. */
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
    shutdown (connection->socket_fd,
              SHUT_WR);
  }
  connection->state = MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED;
  connection->event_loop_info = MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_CLEANUP;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in this function. The fragments in the function are limited to: assigning the daemon pointer, bitmask checks on daemon->options, a call to MHD_tls_connection_shutdown, calls to the system shutdown() API, and setting connection->state and connection->event_loop_info. None of these operations use or imply accesses via pointer parameters to standard string handling routines, so they do not fall under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Note: MHD_tls_connection_shutdown is an external function; if investigation is required for string handling, that function (and any other called functions) should be reviewed separately, but there are no inline uses of <string.h> APIs in this code fragment to report.
